awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Resolving the gene regulatory network alterations responsible for the repeated evolution of a Hox-regulated trait
awd_abstract_narration:
A unifying feature of an organism's appearance (or "phenotype") is its construction during the events of development. Each phenotypic trait requires the cooperation of a collection of genes whose participation is controlled by DNA sequences known as cis-regulatory elements (CREs). CREs work like switches to turn genes ON or OFF in certain cell types at specific life stages. The switch-like function of CREs are encoded in the DNA sequence by short stretches of ordered bases to which proteins known as transcription factors specifically bind. Combinations of transcription factors form a "logic" of instructions that determines precisely which cells, and at what time the CRE can switch a gene ON. Currently, it remains poorly understood how switch-like functions are encoded in CREs and how traits evolve through changes in their encoded logic. In particular, the Hox transcription factors represent a poorly understood class that provides CREs with positional information along the major body axis. The Williams and Rebeiz labs are collaborating to study the network of genes and CREs responsible for making a male-specific body pigmentation of the fruit fly species Drosophila melanogaster. The results will inform how such pigmentation originated and was altered in multiple lineages of fruit fly species. The outcomes will show how the construction of a new characteristic is controlled by Hox genes, CREs and how evolution can operate at the level of binding sites for transcription factors. This work will provide a picture of trait evolution that will be applicable to a wide variety of animal systems. Through this research, computational tools will be refined and online learning resources will be created to aid scientists. This research project will support the future of science personnel through the participation of high school students, undergraduate students, and graduate students in mentored research. Participation will emphasize students from under-represented groups in science.

The developmental events that pattern the animal body plan are regarded as a crucible for the evolution of novel traits. This project's overarching goal is to understand how body plan patterning information originated in a gene regulatory network (GRN), and was subsequently modified to diversify a morphological trait. GRNs are structured to pattern development through the binding of transcription factors to cis-regulatory elements (CREs) to control gene expression. The combination of factors that bind CREs form a regulatory logic that specifies timing, pattern and levels of expression. Currently, very little is known about how GRN structure evolves to generate different phenotypes. Specifically, which genes in the hierarchy were modified, and ultimately how regulatory logic evolves. The Williams and Rebeiz labs are examining the evolution of a GRN and its underlying regulatory logic for a rapidly evolving trait present in an experimentally tractable animal system. The proposed studies will focus on male-specific patterns of abdominal pigmentation that convergently evolved in two fruit fly lineages, which were then modified and lost. The first aim will characterize how the arbiters of the body plan (e.g. Hox proteins, cofactors, and activity modulators) directly interact with CREs of the GRN to control expression patterns of pigmentation enzymes in D. melanogaster. The second aim will determine how this Hox-regulated GRN was altered in cases where pigmentation was expanded, contracted, or lost in non-model fruit fly species. The third aim will trace how this GRN independently evolved a convergent pigmentation phenotype in a non-model fly. To pursue these aims, the research team will employ techniques that include reporter transgenes in multiple fruit fly species and gel shift assays between transcription factors and CRE sequences to pinpoint phenotype altering mutations and connect these to the alterations in transcription factor binding and function that they inspired.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this grant were to investigate how a network of genes (hereafter GRN) was established, altered, and reinvented to generate diverse patterns of fruit fly abdomen pigmentation. After five years of support, nine papers were published. The Principal Investigator, or PI, (Thomas Williams) and Co-PI (Mark Rebeiz) published a review article highlighting various studies of pigmentation patterns among Drosophila (D.) fruit flies that demonstrate the relevant changes that occurred in the DNA sequences that act as switches to turn genes on or off (cis-regulatory elements or CREs), manners by which CREs functionally evolve, and raised conceptual challenges. We published a paper (undergraduate student co-author) on an evolutionarily conserved CRE for a melanic pigmentation gene whose expression-regulating activity underwent a shift in timing of activity during development. We published (undergraduate first-author) how the duplicate bric-a-brac (bab) transcription factor genes were integrated into an evolving pigmentation GRN as a key regulator of limiting melanic pigmentation to the male abdomen. We published on how an ancestral wound response CRE for a pigmentation enzyme was modified to generate an augmented pattern of activity in the fruit fly species D. melanogaster.

Following the origin of male-specific abdomen pigmentation, the trait was lost on several occasions. We published on how changes at several genes contributed to the lost pigmentation of the species D. santomea, including changes that altered the late phase of expression for the body plan regulating Hox gene Abd-B. When abdominal pigmentation patterns are surveyed across the Drosophila genus, male-limited pigmentation is seen in distantly-related lineages, suggesting dimorphism and its GRN were old and repeatedly lost, or that this male-specific trait and its generative GRN evolved more than once. We published a paper in which we surveyed the expression of the pigmentation pathway genes and the Bab1 transcription factor among monomorphic and dimorphic species representing diverse clades. The results show that male-specific pigmentation evolved more than once by the similar deployment of pigmentation enzyme genes by unique regulatory genes.

Decoding the functional information within CREs presents many challenges that remain insurmountable with conventional reporter transgene methods. This includes the natural position of CREs often residing at a distance from the genes that they regulate. We published a paper (2 undergraduate co-authors) that details novel reporter transgene vectors we created that positions CREs between a distant and nearby fluorescent protein gene. This allows one to map the DNA sequences that encode "remote control" activity. A second limitation of reporter transgenes are their typical use in a single, well-established model-organism species. As a result, studies of CREs generally fail to identify differences in the expression of GRN transcription factors. We used a custom-made reporter transgene vector that can perform assays in diverse species. By testing CREs in species with the ancient, modern, modified, and lost dimorphic pigmentation features, we showed how evolution of the trans-regulators (genes that bind to CREs and turn gene expression on or off) is a prominent contributor to fruit fly pigmentation diversity. We developed computational tools for comparative alignment of genome sequences (undergraduate student first author) that can be used with the GenePalette software tool.  

This grant supported training of 5 graduate students, including 2 from a historically excluded groups in science (HEG), 23 undergraduate (UG) students, four of which were from HEGs, and 6 high school students, of which two were from HEGs. 8 UG students completed a thesis mentored by the PI or Co-PI. Students gave 46 poster and 16 oral presentations at meetings. PI and Co-PI and students gave 11 invited presentations on this research. Over the course of the grant, the GenePalette software tool served >2000 new downloads, and novel training video and web content was produced and freely distributed. Co-PI delivered outreach on genetics and evolution to at-risk middle-school students in the Youth Empowerment Project of Sharpsburg. PI and his graduate students gave presentations to STEM students at 3 high schools and 2 middle schools, and are founding members of a UD committee for justice, equality, diversity, and inclusion in Biology. PI organized a seminar series with guest speakers that talk to undergraduate students about STEM careers and career paths.
